item.title: Huawei Executive Took Part in Sanctions Fraud, Prosecutors Say - The New York Times
item.description:
Huawei Executive Took Part in Sanctions Fraud, Prosecutors Say  The New York Times

VANCOUVER, British Columbia — The reasons that the United States asked the Canadian authorities to arrest a top executive of the Chinese technology company Huawei last week had been shrouded in mystery. On Friday, the details of the arrest and what led up to it came out in a Canadian courtroom. At a bail hearing in Vancouver for Meng Wanzhou, the chief financial officer of Huawei and a daughter of the company’s founder, Canadian prosecutors said she was accused of fraud. The heart of the charges related to how Ms. Meng may have participated in a scheme to trick financial institutions into m...

item.title: Huawei seeks to recover from espionage concerns with $2 billion spending pledge - The Telegraph
item.description:
Huawei seeks to recover from espionage concerns with $2 billion spending pledge  The Telegraph

Huawei has pledged to spend an extra $2bn (£1.5bn) to ease concerns raised by British intelligence agency GCHQ over the potential security risk posed by the use of its equipment in the UK’s telecom networks The spending pledge is designed to fix technical concerns over Huawei’s hardware. A government report published in July found that “shortcomings in Huawei’s engineering processes have exposed new risks in the UK telecommunication networks.” Huawei will use the money to improve its production processes in order to allow the government to inspect its devices more easily. The spending pledg...

item.title: Meng Wanzhou Was Huawei’s Professional Face, Until Her Arrest - The New York Times
item.description:
Meng Wanzhou Was Huawei’s Professional Face, Until Her Arrest  The New York Times

BEIJING — As Huawei’s finance chief and daughter of its founder, Meng Wanzhou has been a polished, professional face for a huge technology firm that long was opaque to the outside world. Ms. Meng, the eldest daughter of Ren Zhengfei, the leader of the telecom equipment maker, has appeared before reporters to announce the company’s financial results. She has spoken at company events in New York; Cancún, Mexico; and beyond. She helped inaugurate centers in Britain, a key market for the Chinese giant’s expansion into the Western world. She also sat on the board of a Huawei partner company in H...

item.title: Huawei's Meng charged with conspiracy to defraud banks - The Telegraph
item.description:
Huawei's Meng charged with conspiracy to defraud banks  The Telegraph

Huawei's chief financial officer has been charged with conspiracy to defraud US banks. The company broke US sanctions by doing business in Iran using an unofficial subsidiary, a Canadian court was told on Friday. Its chief financial officer Meng Wanzhou was arrested in the country last week and is wanted in the US over "fraud offences", Vancouver Law Courts heard. The US alleges that Huawei used a subsidiary, Skycom, to do business with Iran, bypassing US sanctions. Ms Meng allegedly misled US financial institutions by telling them that Skycom and Huawei were separate companies, putting the...

item.title: 🇨🇳Huawei CFO’s arrest rattles investors, markets tumble l Al Jazeera English - Al Jazeera English
item.description:
🇨🇳Huawei CFO’s arrest rattles investors, markets tumble l Al Jazeera English  Al Jazeera English

American stocks clawed back much of the ground lost in an early plunge triggered by the news of the arrest of Huawei Technologies CFO, Meng Wanzhou, in Canada at the United States’ request. The initial drop joined a global rout, reviving worries over trade tensions. Meng’s arrest threatens to drive a wedge between the US and China just days after they agreed on a 90-day trade-war truce in Argentina on Saturday. Al Jazeera's Kristen Saloomey reports. - Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www....

item.title: Huawei finance chief Meng Wanzhou to appear in court as Chinese media react furiously to arrest - The Independent
item.description:
Huawei finance chief Meng Wanzhou to appear in court as Chinese media react furiously to arrest  The Independent

Huawei’s finance chief is set to appear at a bail hearing in Vancouver on Friday amid a backlash in Chinese media over her detention. Chief financial officer Meng Wanzhou, daughter of Huawei founder Ren Zhengfei, was arrested by Canadian authorities on Saturday at the request of the US government which is seeking extradition. No official reason has been given but it is thought to be linked to alleged violations of US sanctions on Iran. Stock markets calmed on Friday following a tumultuous session on Thursday as news of Ms Meng’s detention prompted fears of a new front on the US-China trade ...

item.title: US case against Huawei CFO revealed in Canadian court - CNN
item.description:
US case against Huawei CFO revealed in Canadian court  CNN

The United States is claiming that the chief financial officer of Chinese tech giant Huawei covered up violations of sanctions on Iran, according to Canadian prosecutors. Meng Wanzhou, who was arrested in Vancouver and faces extradition to the United States, is believed to have helped Huawei circumvent US sanctions by telling financial institutions that a Huawei subsidiary was a separate company, prosecutors said at a hearing Friday to determine whether Meng should be released on bail. Her lawyer said that she has ties to Canada and is not a flight risk. The judge, after hearing arguments f...

item.title: Europe should be wary of Huawei, EU tech official says - Reuters
item.description:
Europe should be wary of Huawei, EU tech official says  Reuters

The European Union should be worried about Huawei [HWT.UL] and other Chinese technology companies because of the risk they pose to the bloc's industry and security, the EU's technology chief said on Friday, echoing concerns raised elsewhere in the world. Huawei expressed disappointment at EU tech commissioner Andrus Ansip's comments, saying it had never been asked to install technology that could be used for spying and never would. "Do we have to be worried about Huawei or other Chinese companies? Yes, I think we have to be worried about those companies," Ansip told a news conference in Bru...

item.title: What is Huawei, and why the arrest of its CFO matters - CNN
item.description:
What is Huawei, and why the arrest of its CFO matters  CNN

The arrest of a top Huawei executive has roiled the business world and threatens to derail the tenuous trade truce between the United States and China. Meng Wanzhou, the Chinese tech company's chief financial officer, was detained in Vancouver on Saturday at the request of US authorities. She's accused by the United States of helping Huawei cover up violations of sanctions on Iran, according to Canadian prosecutors. US lawmakers are condemning Huawei, which they say poses a national security threat to the United States. Chinese officials have called for Meng's release. An op-ed in the Chine...

item.title: Who Is Meng Wanzhou? - CNN
item.description:
Who Is Meng Wanzhou?  CNN

Meng Wanzhou, also known as Sabrina Meng and Cathy Meng, is the chief financial officer and deputy chairwoman of the board of Chinese tech firm Huawei. ©2018 Cable News Network, Inc. A WarnerMedia Company. All Rights Reserved.

item.title: Who is Meng Wanzhou, the Chinese exec wanted by the US? - CNN
item.description:
Who is Meng Wanzhou, the Chinese exec wanted by the US?  CNN

Meng Wanzhou, the CFO of Chinese tech giant Huawei, has kept a low profile for much of her career. Now she's at the center of a geopolitical drama between the world's two largest economies. The 46-year-old executive was arrested Saturday in Canada, and faces extradition to the United States. After news of her arrest broke late Wednesday, Meng's face was splashed across the internet. Meng is the daughter of Huawei's billionaire founder, Ren Zhangfei, and her case threatens to ramp up tensions between Washington and Beijing. "The fact that this is Ren's daughter and a very senior official in ...

item.title: Asian markets plunge, led by tech stocks, after Huawei exec’s arrest - MarketWatch
item.description:
Asian markets plunge, led by tech stocks, after Huawei exec’s arrest  MarketWatch

ASIA MARKETS By MarketWatch and Associated Press Hang Seng tumbles nearly 2.5%; Nikkei falls about 2% A man walks by a Huawei logo at a shopping mall in Shanghai, China, on Wednesday. Reuters Asian stock prices fell Thursday, led by tumbling tech stocks, following the arrest of a senior official at Chinese telecom equipment maker Huawei that could derail progress in China-U.S. trade talks. Canadian authorities arrested the chief financial officer of Huawei Technologies for possible extradition to the United States, for allegedly violating sanctions against Iran. Meng Wanzhou was detained in...

item.title: Oppo R17 Pro Review: The World's Fastest Charging Phone - Forbes
item.description:
Oppo R17 Pro Review: The World's Fastest Charging Phone  Forbes

The Oppo R17 Pro with its gorgeous gradient-colored back. Most Chinese smartphone brands nowadays pump out four, five, or six devices a year, to a market that’s already beyond saturate. Many of these manufacturers barely differentiate each of these handsets, so much so that they tend to get lost in the noise and are forgotten quickly. However Oppo, for the most part, has done a solid job of making sure each release is worth covering, with at least one head-turning feature. The Find X, for example, was an absolute stunner in design and craftsmanship and will likely end up in one of the top t...

item.title: Huawei Executive's Arrest Threatens To Derail Company's Global Ambitions - Forbes
item.description:
Huawei Executive's Arrest Threatens To Derail Company's Global Ambitions  Forbes

Attendees stand at the Huawei Technologies booth at the Mobile World Congress Shanghai on June 28, 2018. (Photo: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg) The arrest of a senior executive at telecom equipment supplier Huawei Technologies will likely give rise to more security concerns in other countries closely allied with the U.S. and jeopardize the company’s future revenue streams. Huawei’s Chief Financial Officer Meng Wanzhou, who is also the daughter of the company’s founder Ren Zhengfei, was detained in Vancouver and faces possible extradition to the U.S. While the charges against Meng haven’t been specif...

item.title: Ericsson sorry for software glitch that hits mobile services in Britain and Japan - Reuters
item.description:
Ericsson sorry for software glitch that hits mobile services in Britain and Japan  Reuters

Sweden's Ericsson (ERICb.ST: Quote, Profile, Research, Stock Buzz) apologized and said it was working hard to fix a software glitch that was responsible for millions of smartphone users in Britain, Japan and other countries losing internet access on Thursday. O2 (TEF.MC: Quote, Profile, Research, Stock Buzz), Britain's second biggest network, and Japan's Softbank (9984.T: Quote, Profile, Research, Stock Buzz), both Ericsson customers, reported outages on their 4G networks earlier on Thursday. The mobile network equipment maker confirmed that a problem with its software was to blame for the ...

item.title: The Latest: Huawei awaits 'right conclusion' in CFO's arrest - The Associated Press
item.description:
The Latest: Huawei awaits 'right conclusion' in CFO's arrest  The Associated Press

WASHINGTON (AP) — The Latest on the arrest of an executive of Chinese telecoms equipment maker Huawei Technologies (all times local): 11:45 p.m. Chinese telecommunications giant Huawei says it has "every confidence that the Canadian and U.S. legal systems will reach the right conclusion" over the arrest of one of its top executives in Canada. Huawei released a brief statement Saturday in China following a bail hearing in Vancouver for Meng Wanzou, its chief financial officer and the daughter of its founder. She faces possible extradition to the U.S, where officials allege that Huawei used a...

item.title: 🇨🇦🇨🇳Canada arrests CFO of Chinese telecoms giant Huawei | Al Jazeera English - Al Jazeera English
item.description:
🇨🇦🇨🇳Canada arrests CFO of Chinese telecoms giant Huawei | Al Jazeera English  Al Jazeera English

Meng Wanzhou, chief financial officer of Chinese telecoms giant Huawei, has been arrested in Vancouver, Canada on December 1 and faces extradition to the United States. "She is sought for extradition by the United States, and a bail hearing has been set for Friday," Canada's justice ministry said, adding it could not provide further details due to a publication ban that was sought by and granted to Meng. Earlier this year, US media reported that the US was investigating Huawei for violating sanctions on Iran by selling network equipment to the country. Al Jazeera's Adrian Brown reports from...

item.title: Report: Huawei’s troubles may be worsening as Japan and British Telecom weigh bans - Fast Company
item.description:
Report: Huawei’s troubles may be worsening as Japan and British Telecom weigh bans  Fast Company

Things are getting even worse for Chinese telecom giant Huawei. British Telecom, one of the UK’s largest internet providers, said this week it will not use Huawei’s equipment in its 5G mobile network when it is rolled out in the UK, according to the BBC. Japan is also reportedly limiting the use of Huawei components in government-backed networks. These moves date back to 2012, when Huawei and its rival Chinese telecom, ZTE Corp, were the subjects of a U.S. Congressional investigation into whether their equipment could pose a threat to U.S. security. Congress issued a report concluding that ...

item.title: Huawei: Chinese media accuses US of 'hooliganism' over Meng Wanzhou arrest - The Guardian
item.description:
Huawei: Chinese media accuses US of 'hooliganism' over Meng Wanzhou arrest  The Guardian

Chinese media have lashed out at the US over the arrest of senior Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou, accusing the country of using “hooliganism” to suppress the Chinese telecom giant at the centre of what is turning into a major diplomatic incident. State-run China Daily said the arrest of Huawei’s chief financial officer appeared to be part of US efforts to contain the company, which is the world’s largest telecoms equipment provider, as well as its second-largest mobile phone maker. “One thing that is undoubtedly true and proven is the US is trying to do whatever it can to contain Huawei’s ex...

item.title: A Second Silicon Valley In China Rattles The U.S. Tech Elite And DC - Think Huawei - Forbes
item.description:
A Second Silicon Valley In China Rattles The U.S. Tech Elite And DC - Think Huawei  Forbes

Huawei retail shop in Beijing Ongoing frictions over China’s growing technology innovation edge are highlighted by the U.S. recent arrest of Huawei’s CFO who is the daughter of the founder. The widespread news of charges against Huawei — whether for questionable financial transactions or violations of Iran sanctions — underscore the increasing power and impact that Chinese tech companies now have in the West. Chinese leaders such as Huawei have become a competitive challenge for the U.S. tech elite. Huawei is the world’s largest smartphone maker, not Apple. The backdrop is the rise of Chi...
